description: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is a U.S. federal agency responsible for protecting public health by ensuring the safety, efficacy, and security of human and veterinary drugs, biological products, medical devices, food, cosmetics, and tobacco products. It regulates the development and marketing of these products, monitors adverse events, and enforces laws to ensure compliance with standards that promote consumer safety and innovation.

The European Medicines Agency (EMA) is a decentralized agency of the European Union responsible for evaluating, monitoring, and approving medicinal products for human and veterinary use across Europe. Headquartered in Amsterdam, the EMA ensures the safety, efficacy, and quality of medicines, fostering innovation while safeguarding public and animal health.

The World Health Organization (WHO) is a specialized agency of the United Nations responsible for international public health. Established in 1948, its primary role is to coordinate global health responses, set health standards, and provide leadership on critical health issues to promote better health outcomes worldwide.

fullName: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency
description: The MHRA is a UK government agency responsible for regulating medicines, medical devices, and blood components for transfusion, ensuring their safety, quality, and effectiveness.
Health Canada is the federal department responsible for helping Canadians maintain and improve their health, including regulating drugs, medical devices, and other health products.
The TGA is the regulatory authority for therapeutic goods in Australia, ensuring their safety, quality, and efficacy for public use.
The Paul-Ehrlich-Institut is Germany's federal institute for vaccines and biomedicines, responsible for approving and monitoring vaccines, blood products, and other biomedicines.
The NMPA is the Chinese government agency responsible for the regulation of drugs, medical devices, and cosmetics, ensuring their safety, quality, and efficacy.
The CDSCO is India's national regulatory body for pharmaceuticals and medical devices, ensuring their safety, efficacy, and quality.
The PMDA is Japan's regulatory body that evaluates and approves drugs, medical devices, and regenerative medical products, ensuring their safety and efficacy.

fullName: Federal Commission for the Protection against Sanitary Risk
description: COFEPRIS is the Mexican regulatory authority responsible for health control, including the regulation of drugs, medical devices, and other health-related products.
The HSA is Singapore's regulatory body that ensures the safety, efficacy, and quality of drugs, medical devices, and other health products.

fullName: South African Health Products Regulatory Authority
description: SAHPRA is the national regulatory authority in South Africa, responsible for regulating health products, including medicines and medical devices, to ensure their safety and efficacy.
ANVISA is Brazil's regulatory authority responsible for the approval, regulation, and monitoring of drugs, medical devices, and other health products.

fullName: Federal Service for Surveillance in Healthcare (Roszdravnadzor)
description: Roszdravnadzor is Russia’s federal executive body under the Ministry of Health responsible for regulation, supervision, and enforcement in medical care, pharmaceuticals, medical devices, and clinical practices, ensuring safety, quality, and compliance across healthcare.
Swissmedic is the Swiss agency for therapeutic products, responsible for the authorization and supervision of drugs and medical devices in Switzerland.

fullName: National Institute of Pharmacy and Nutrition
description: This Hungarian institution is responsible for the regulation and safety of pharmaceuticals, medical devices, and nutritional products in Hungary.

fullName: Agence nationale de sécurité du médicament et des produits de santé
description: ANSM is the French regulatory agency responsible for ensuring the safety, efficacy, and quality of medicines and health products.
AIFA is the national authority in Italy responsible for the regulation, approval, and monitoring of medicines, ensuring their safety and effectiveness.

fullName: Spanish Agency of Medicines and Medical Devices
description: AEMPS is the Spanish agency responsible for the regulation, monitoring, and control of medicines and medical devices in Spain.

fullName: Ministry of Food and Drug Safety
description: MFDS is the South Korean regulatory authority that ensures the safety and efficacy of food, drugs, and medical devices.
SUKL is the Czech Republic's national regulatory authority for medicines and medical devices, ensuring their safety, efficacy, and quality.
DKMA is Denmark's regulatory authority responsible for the approval, regulation, and safety of medicines and medical devices.
FIMEA is Finland's regulatory authority responsible for the evaluation, authorization, and supervision of medicines and medical devices.
EOF is Greece's national regulatory authority responsible for the safety, efficacy, and quality of medicines and medical devices.
The IMA is Iceland's regulatory authority responsible for the safety, efficacy, and quality of medicines and medical devices.
The IMB, now known as the Health Products Regulatory Authority (HPRA), is Ireland's regulatory body responsible for the safety, quality, and efficacy of medicines and medical devices.
SIDC is Slovakia's national regulatory authority for the control of medicines and medical devices, ensuring their safety and effectiveness.

fullName: Agency for Medicinal Products and Medical Devices of the Republic of Slovenia (JAZMP)
description: JAZMP is Slovenia’s independent national regulatory authority responsible for the regulation, evaluation, supervision, and vigilance of human and veterinary medicinal products and medical devices, ensuring their safety, efficacy, and quality.
The MPA is Sweden's regulatory authority responsible for ensuring the safety, efficacy, and quality of medicines and medical devices.
MEB is the Dutch regulatory body responsible for the assessment and monitoring of medicines to ensure their safety and efficacy in the Netherlands.
NoMA is Norway's national authority responsible for the regulation and safety of medicines and medical devices.
The Medicines Authority in Malta is responsible for regulating the safety, efficacy, and quality of medicines and medical devices.

fullName: National Agency for Medicines and Medical Devices
description: NAMMD is Romania's regulatory authority that oversees the safety, efficacy, and quality of medicines and medical devices.

fullName: Agency for Medicinal Products and Medical Devices
description: HALMED is Croatia's national regulatory authority responsible for the safety and quality of medicines and medical devices.
The Cyprus Pharmaceutical Services is the national authority responsible for the regulation and control of medicines and medical devices in Cyprus.
SAM is Estonia's national regulatory authority for the safety, efficacy, and quality of medicines and medical devices.
INFARMED is Portugal's regulatory authority responsible for ensuring the safety, efficacy, and quality of medicines and health products.

fullName: National Institute for Food and Drug Surveillance (INVIMA)
description: he Instituto Nacional de Vigilancia de Medicamentos y Alimentos (INVIMA) is Colombia’s national regulatory authority under the Ministry of Health, responsible for overseeing the quality, safety, and efficacy of medicines, medical devices, food, cosmetics, vaccines, and biological products.

fullName: National Agency for Food and Drug Administration and Control-NAFDAC
description: NAFDAC is Nigeria's regulatory authority responsible for ensuring the safety, efficacy, and quality of drugs, food, medical devices, and other health products.
The EDA is Egypt's national regulatory authority responsible for the oversight, regulation, and control of pharmaceuticals, medical devices, and other health-related products.

fullName: National Administration of Drugs, Foods and Medical Devices-ANMAT
description: ANMAT is the regulatory body in Argentina that ensures the safety, efficacy, and quality of medicines, foods, and medical devices.
The ISP in Chile is responsible for the regulation and oversight of public health, including the evaluation and approval of medicines, medical devices, and other health products.
The Ministry of Health in Israel is responsible for public health policy, regulation of health products, and ensuring the safety and efficacy of medicines and medical devices.

fullName: Turkish Medicines and Medical Devices Agency (Türkiye İlaç ve Tıbbi Cihaz Kurumu - TİTCK)
description: The Turkish Ministry of Health oversees public health services, regulates the pharmaceutical industry, and ensures the safety and quality of health products in Turkey.

An independent regulatory authority directly under the Council of Ministers, responsible for ensuring the safety, quality, efficacy, and security of food, drugs (human & veterinary), biologicals, cosmetics, pesticides, medical devices, feed, bottled water and radiation‑emitting equipment in Saudi Arabia.
The UAE Ministry of Health oversees healthcare services, regulates pharmaceuticals and medical devices, and ensures public health and safety across the Emirates.
The Ministry of Health in Kuwait is responsible for public health policy, healthcare services, and the regulation of medicines and medical devices in the country.
The Qatari Ministry of Health manages public health services, regulates pharmaceuticals, and ensures the safety and efficacy of health products in Qatar.

The NHRA is an independent regulatory authority under Bahrain’s Ministry of Health, mandated to regulate the full spectrum of health services—healthcare facilities, professionals, medical devices, medicines, and clinical trials—across both public and private sectors
The Omani Ministry of Health is responsible for public health services, regulation of pharmaceuticals, and ensuring the safety of health products in Oman.
The Ministry of Health in Jordan oversees healthcare services, regulates medicines and medical devices, and promotes public health in the country.
The Lebanese Ministry of Health is responsible for public health policies, healthcare services, and the regulation of pharmaceuticals and medical devices in Lebanon.
The Iraqi Ministry of Health oversees public health services, regulates medicines and medical devices, and ensures the safety and efficacy of health products in Iraq.
The Ministry of Health in Syria is responsible for public health policy, healthcare services, and the regulation of health products in the country.
The Afghan Ministry of Health is responsible for overseeing healthcare services, regulating health products, and ensuring public health in Afghanistan.

The Drug Regulatory Authority of Pakistan (DRAP), established under the DRAP Act 2012 and operating under the Ministry of National Health Services, Regulations & Coordination, is the national regulatory body responsible for ensuring the quality, safety, and efficacy of therapeutic goods in Pakistan.

The DGDA is Bangladesh’s principal regulatory authority under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, tasked with ensuring the quality, safety, efficacy, and affordability of all pharmaceutical products — including allopathic, Ayurvedic, Unani, herbal, and homeopathic medicines.

The NMRA, established in 2015 under NMRA Act No. 5 of 2015, is Sri Lanka’s independent regulatory authority under the Ministry of Health responsible for safeguarding public health through ensuring that medicinal products, medical devices, cosmetics, borderline products, and clinical trials meet standards of safety, efficacy, quality—and are available and affordable.

The Department of Drug Administration (DDA) is Nepal’s national drug regulatory authority under the Ministry of Health and Population. Established in 1979, DDA operates under the Drug Act of 1978 and oversees registration and licensing of medicines, pharmacovigilance, clinical trial approval, quality-control testing, facility inspections, and market surveillance.

BFDA is Bhutan’s national authority responsible for regulating food, medicinal products (including traditional medicines and medical devices), controlled substances, biosecurity, agricultural products, and chemicals to protect public health.

The Maldives Food and Drug Authority (MFDA) is the national regulatory agency under the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Maldives. MFDA oversees the safety, quality, and efficacy of food, medicines, medical devices, therapeutic goods, and related products.
The Ministry of Health in Indonesia is responsible for public health policy, healthcare services, and the regulation of medicines and medical devices.

The National Pharmaceutical Regulatory Agency (NPRA) is Malaysia’s national regulatory authority under the Ministry of Health, responsible for ensuring the safety, quality, and efficacy of medicines and cosmetics. It oversees product registration, licensing of manufacturers and importers, laboratory testing, pharmacovigilance, market surveillance, and clinical trial approval.

fullName: Thai Food and Drug Administration (Thai FDA)
description: The Thai FDA is Thailand's national regulatory authority under the Ministry of Public Health, responsible for ensuring the safety, quality, and efficacy of health products including food, drugs, medical devices, cosmetics, herbal products, narcotics, psychotropic and volatile substances.
The Ministry of Health in Vietnam oversees public health services, regulates pharmaceuticals, and ensures the safety and efficacy of health products in the country.
The Cambodian Ministry of Health is responsible for public health services, regulation of pharmaceuticals, and ensuring the safety and quality of health products in the country.

fullName: Food and Drug Department of the Ministry of Health
description: The Food and Drug Department (FDD) of the Ministry of Health in Lao PDR is the national regulatory authority responsible for ensuring the safety, quality, and efficacy of food, medicines (including traditional and modern products), supplements, and medical devices.
The Ministry of Health in Myanmar is responsible for public health policy, healthcare services, and the regulation of medicines and medical devices.

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) of the Philippines, established in 1963 and strengthened under Republic Act No. 9711 (2009), is the national regulatory agency under the Department of Health. FDA ensures the safety, quality, and efficacy of food, medicines, medical devices, cosmetics, biologicals, vaccines, radiation‑emitting equipment, household hazardous products, and tobacco. It manages product registration and licensing, field inspections, laboratory testing, pharmacovigilance, clinical trial oversight, promotional and advertising compliance, and enforcement actions. As of 2025, the agency is headed by Director General Atty. Paolo S. Teston and operates through specialized centers and regional field clusters
The Ministry of Health in Brunei oversees public health services, regulates pharmaceuticals, and ensures the safety and quality of health products in the country.

The Ministry of Health in Tajikistan is responsible for public health policy, healthcare services, and the regulation of medicines and medical devices.

fullName: Scientific Centre of Drug and Medical Technology Expertise (SCDMTE)
description: A public expertise body under Armenia’s Ministry of Health responsible for scientific evaluation and state registration of medicinal products—including veterinary and herbal drugs—and medical devices (including cosmetics and medical equipment).
The Ministry of Health in Azerbaijan is responsible for public health policy, healthcare services, and the regulation of medicines and medical devices.

fullName: Center for Expert Evaluation and Testing in Healthcare (RCETH)
description: RCETH is a Republican Unitary Enterprise under the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Belarus, responsible for expert examination and quality control of medicinal products and medical devices in line with national and Eurasian Economic Union regulations.
The Ministry of Health in Ukraine oversees public health services, regulates pharmaceuticals, and ensures the safety and quality of health products in the country.

fullName: National Agency for Medicines and Medical Devices (AMDM)
description: The National Agency for Medicines and Medical Devices (AMDM) is Moldova’s regulatory authority under the Ministry of Health. Established as a public legal entity, AMDM oversees the registration, evaluation, and surveillance of medicines and medical devices.

fullName: Medicines and Medical Devices Agency of Serbia (ALIMS)
description: ALIMS is Serbia’s national regulatory authority under the Ministry of Health, responsible for ensuring that human and veterinary medicines and medical devices meet national standards of quality, safety, and efficacy.
The Ministry of Health in Montenegro is responsible for public health policy, healthcare services, and the regulation of medicines and medical devices.

fullName: Agency for Medicinal Products and Medical Devices of Bosnia and Herzegovina (ALMBiH)
description: The Agency for Medicinal Products and Medical Devices of Bosnia and Herzegovina (ALMBiH) is the national regulatory authority responsible for the registration, evaluation, and monitoring of medicines and medical devices. Established in 2009, ALMBiH ensures the safety, efficacy, and quality of medicinal products throughout the country. The agency regulates clinical trials, oversees pharmacovigilance activities, and performs market surveillance and inspections. ALMBiH also works to harmonize its regulatory framework with European Union standards and cooperates with international regulatory bodies to strengthen public health protections.
The Ministry of Health in North Macedonia is responsible for public health policy, healthcare services, and the regulation of medicines and medical devices.

fullName: National Agency for Medicines and Medical Devices (AKBPM)
description: AKBPM is Albania’s national regulatory authority responsible for the regulation, evaluation, supervision, and control of human medicines and medical devices in the country, ensuring their quality, safety, and efficacy.

The Botswana Medicines Regulatory Authority (BoMRA) is the national body responsible for regulating medicines, medical devices, and related substances in Botswana. It ensures their safety, quality, and efficacy through registration, inspections, and pharmacovigilance.
The Ministry of Health in Burkina Faso oversees public health services, regulates medicines, and ensures the safety and quality of health products in the country.

fullName: Agence Burundaise de Régulation des Médicaments à usage humain et des Aliments (ABREMA)
description: he Autorité Burundaise de Régulation des Médicaments à usage humain et des Aliments (ABREMA) is Burundi’s national regulatory authority, established in 2021. It operates under the Ministry of Public Health and is responsible for regulating and overseeing human medicines, food products, medical devices, cosmetics, and traditional health-related products.

The Entidade Reguladora Independente da Saúde (ERIS) — also known as the Independent Health Regulatory Entity in Cabo Verde — is the national authority responsible for regulating, authorising, and overseeing medicines, medical devices, food, and cosmetics.

fullName: Department of Pharmacy, Medicines, and Laboratories (DPML)
description: The Department of Pharmacy, Drugs and Laboratories (DPML) is a core technical department within Cameroon’s Ministry of Public Health. Established under Decree No. 2013/093 (April 2013), it serves as the central coordinating body of the national pharmaceutical regulatory authority
The Ministry of Health in the Central African Republic oversees public health services, regulates medicines, and ensures the safety and quality of health products in the country.

ANAMEV is responsible for regulating medicines, medical products, and medical devices, ensuring their quality, safety, and efficacy.

The Ministry of Health in Eswatini (Swaziland) is responsible for public health policy, healthcare services, and the regulation of medicines and medical devices in the country.

The Ethiopian Food and Drug Authority (EFDA) is the national regulatory body under Ethiopia’s Ministry of Health, established by Proclamation No. 1263/2021 and Regulation No. 531/2023. EFDA ensures the safety, quality, and effectiveness of food, medicines, medical devices, cosmetics, alcohol, and tobacco products.

The Fiji Medicines Regulatory Authority (Fiji MRA), operating within the Fiji Pharmaceutical & Biomedical Services Centre of the Ministry of Health, is the national regulatory authority responsible for ensuring that medicines and medical devices in Fiji are safe, effective, and of high quality.
The Ministry of Health in Gabon oversees public health services, regulates pharmaceuticals, and ensures the safety and quality of health products in the country.

The Medicines Control Agency (MCA) is The Gambia’s national regulatory authority under the Ministry of Health, established by the Medicines and Related Products Act 2014. MCA ensures the quality, safety, and efficacy of medicines and related products—including herbal medicines, cosmetics, household chemicals, and medical devices—through product registration, licensing, inspection, pharmacovigilance, quality-control testing, clinical trial oversight, and market surveillance. MCA is committed to becoming a center of excellence in pharmaceutical regulation.

The Food and Drugs Authority (FDA) is Ghana’s national regulatory authority under the Ministry of Health, established under the Food and Drugs Act, 1992 (PNDCL 305B) and reconstituted by the Public Health Act, 2012 (Act 851).

The Autorité Ivoirienne de Régulation Pharmaceutique (AIRP) is Côte d’Ivoire’s independent public authority, established by Law No. 2017‑541 in August 2017. AIRP regulates and oversees the registration, quality control, import licensing, and market surveillance of pharmaceuticals, medical devices, pharmacies, and clinical laboratories.
The Ministry of Health in Jamaica oversees public health services, regulates medicines, and ensures the safety and quality of health products in the country.

The Pharmacy and Poisons Board (PPB) is Kenya’s national regulatory authority established under the Pharmacy and Poisons Act (Cap 244). Operating under the Ministry of Health, PPB licenses and oversees the pharmacy profession and the manufacture, distribution, and trade in medicines and poisons. Its core responsibilities include product evaluation and registration, facility and professional licensure, inspection of pharmaceutical premises, pharmacovigilance, clinical trial oversight, quality control, and enforcement of Good Manufacturing and Distribution Practices
The Ministry of Health in Kiribati oversees public health services, regulates pharmaceuticals, and ensures the safety and efficacy of health products in the country.

fullName: Liberia Medicines & Health Products Regulatory Authority (LMHRA)
description: The Liberia Medicines & Health Products Regulatory Authority (LMHRA) is Liberia’s national regulatory authority, established in September 2010. The Agence du Médicament de Madagascar (AGMED) is Madagascar’s national drug regulatory authority under the Ministry of Health. he Pharmacy and Medicines Regulatory Authority (PMRA) is Malawi’s statutory national regulatory body established under the PMRA Act No. 9 of 2019. fullName: Supreme Board of Drugs and Medical Appliances (SBDMA)
description: The Supreme Board of Drugs and Medical Appliances (SBDMA) is Yemen’s national regulatory authority responsible for overseeing regulation, supply, and quality control of pharmaceuticals and medical devices. It regulates the development and marketing of these products, monitors adverse events, and enforces laws to ensure compliance with standards that promote consumer safety and innovation.

description: Responsible for public health policy, licensing, and oversight of vaccines in Algeria.

description: Oversees healthcare and immunization in Andorra; no separate dedicated vaccine regulatory authority.

description: Handles vaccine development, authorization, and market surveillance in Austria.

fullName: Ministry of Health and Wellness (Bahamas) with reliance on Caribbean Regulatory System (CRS) and CARPHA
description: Coordinates vaccine licensing in The Bahamas with regulatory support from CRS and CARPHA.
Historical entity; now part of modern Germany—vaccine regulation covered by German federal authorities (e.g., BfArM, Paul-Ehrlich-Institut).

fullName: Federal Agency for Medicines and Health Products
description: Responsible for approval, registration, and pharmacovigilance of vaccines and medicines in Belgium.
Burkina Faso’s national pharmaceutical regulatory authority, responsible for licensing vaccines and other medicines.
Historical entity; now part of modern Germany—vaccine regulation covered by German federal authorities.
Burkina Faso’s national pharmaceutical regulatory authority, responsible for licensing vaccines and other medicines.

fullName: Food and Drug Administration (FDA) / Food and Drug Board of Authority (FDBA)
description: Myanmar’s national authority overseeing regulation and licensing of vaccines, drugs, and medical products.
Monitors and regulates healthcare services in the Cayman Islands; vaccine administration provided via Health Services Authority.
Historical entity; no modern licensing authority—Central American Federation dissolved in the 19th century.
Historical entity (1885–1908); modern vaccine regulation falls under the Democratic Republic of the Congo’s current authorities.
Established under the Biosecurity Act 2008, oversees ecological and quarantine control; no dedicated vaccine licensing agency identified.

fullName: Ministry of Health – National Commission of Vaccination and Epidemiology (CNVE)
description: Costa Rica’s Ministry of Health oversees vaccination policy via the CNVE, which determines immunization schedules and mandates.
Ivory Coast’s national pharmaceutical regulatory authority responsible for vaccine and medicine approvals, including COVID-19 vaccines.

fullName: Centro para el Control Estatal de Medicamentos, Equipos y Dispositivos Médicos
description: Cuba’s national regulatory authority for pharmaceuticals and vaccines, responsible for licensing and ensuring safety and efficacy.
Czechia’s national competent authority for medicines and vaccine licensing and surveillance.
Historical entity; no modern successor—vaccine regulation now handled by Czechia’s SÚKL.
Historical entity; no modern successor—vaccine regulation handled by modern Italian or European authorities.
Historical entity (East Germany, GDR); current vaccine regulation in the region now under Germany’s BfArM or Paul-Ehrlich-Institut.
Historical entity (Federal Government of Germany 1848-49); no modern authority—covered by current German regulatory bodies.
The Gambia’s national regulatory authority responsible for the approval, registration, and oversight of vaccines and medicines under the Medicines and Related Products Act 2014.
Historical entity (Grand Duchy of Tuscany); modern Italy’s regulatory bodies oversee vaccine regulation.
Historical entity; no modern successor—vaccine regulation now handled by Italian (or EU) authorities.
Historical entity; no modern successor—regulation handled by modern Germany’s regulatory bodies.
Historical entity (Kingdom of Hawaii,* etc.); modern vaccine regulation falls under United States federal authorities (e.g., FDA).
Historical entity; part of modern Germany—vaccine regulation under national authorities (e.g., BfArM, Paul-Ehrlich-Institut).

The Holy See (Vatican City) does not operate a distinct national vaccine regulatory authority—health services (e.g., seasonal flu, COVID-19 vaccination) are provided via Apostolic institutions; no formal licensor body.

fullName: Medicines and Medical Devices Agency of Serbia
description: Serbia’s national regulatory authority responsible for regulation and surveillance of vaccines, medicines, and medical devices, operating under the Ministry of Health.

fullName: Ministry of Food and Drug Safety
description: South Korea’s national regulatory authority responsible for ensuring the safety and effectiveness of vaccines, medicines, foods, and medical devices; recognized by WHO at the highest maturity level (ML4).
Latvia’s national authority for the certification, approval, and regulation of vaccines and medicines.
Historical entity (Ryukyu Kingdom); no modern licensing authority—vaccine regulation falls under Japan’s national agencies.
Lithuania’s national regulatory authority overseeing the evaluation, supervision, and licensing of medicines and vaccines for human use.
Historical entity; vaccine regulation is now managed by modern German federal agencies (e.g., BfArM, Paul-Ehrlich-Institut).
Historical entity; vaccine regulation now under modern Germany’s federal authorities.

fullName: Agence Nationale de la Pharmacie (ANPM) / Directorate of Medicines & Pharmacy (DMP) of the Ministry of Health
description: Morocco’s national authority responsible for licensing and overseeing vaccines and medicines through its Directorate of Medicines and Pharmacy.
Historical entity; modern vaccine regulation is under Italian (EU) authorities.

fullName: New Zealand Medicines and Medical Devices Safety Authority
description: The national regulator responsible for approving and monitoring vaccines and therapeutic products in New Zealand.
Self-governing state in free association with New Zealand; vaccine regulation and oversight are handled by New Zealand’s authorities (e.g., Medsafe).
Historical entity; vaccine regulation now falls under modern Germany’s federal agencies (e.g., BfArM, Paul-Ehrlich-Institut).
Historical entity; present-day regulation handled by Germany’s federal authorities.
Historical entity; modern Germany’s federal agencies now oversee vaccine regulation.
Historical entity (Orange Free State); vaccine regulation now managed by modern South African federal authorities.
Historical entity (Papal States); no modern successor—health and vaccine regulation under Italian and EU authorities.
Historical entity (Piedmont-Sardinia); modern vaccine regulation under Italian and EU regulatory bodies.

fullName: Office for Registration of Medicinal Products, Medical Devices and Biocidal Products
description: Poland’s national authority responsible for registration, approval, and oversight of vaccines and medicinal products, working alongside the Chief Pharmaceutical Inspectorate.
Historical entity (Republic of Genoa); modern vaccine regulation handled by Italy’s national and EU regulators.

fullName: Ministry of Food and Drug Safety
description: South Korea’s national authority responsible for ensuring safety and effectiveness of vaccines and medicines.

fullName: Direction de la Pharmacie et du Médicament (DPM)
description: The Republic of the Congo’s national regulatory authority overseeing vaccine and medicine approval and pharmacovigilance.
Historical entity; modern vaccine regulation in this region falls under Germany’s federal authorities.
Sudan’s semi-autonomous medicines regulatory authority responsible for licensing vaccines and medicines and overseeing pharmacovigilance.
Sub-national U.S. state: vaccine licensing and regulation fall under federal agencies (e.g., FDA), with immunization programs administered by the Texas Department of State Health Services.
Timor-Leste’s national authority responsible for health policy, pharmaceutical regulation, and oversight of immunization programs.
Historical entity; modern vaccine regulation now managed by Italian and EU authorities.
Historical entity; successor countries now have individual regulatory authorities (e.g., Russia’s Ministry of Health).
Uruguay’s national authority responsible for public health policy, regulation of medicines and vaccines, and health system oversight.

fullName: Ministry of Popular Power for Health (MPPS) / Rafael Rangel National Hygiene Institute (INHRR)
description: Venezuela’s primary health authorities overseeing vaccine regulation, licensing, and epidemiologic surveillance.

Historical state in present-day Germany; no current licensing authority. Today, vaccine regulation in the region is handled by Germany’s Paul-Ehrlich-Institut (PEI) under the Federal Ministry of Health.
